qas.question: What food related trend was significant in the new agrarian societies?
What forms of availability dictated Pre-agrarian diets?
What was included in the Post-agrarian diet?

answers.text: cereal grains, plants and to a variable extent domesticated animals and animal products.

qas.question: What forced the need to supplement food supply with hunting and gathering?
What food related trend was significant in restricted societies?
What forms of availability dictated local diets?

plausible_answers.text: cereal grains, plants and to a variable extent domesticated animals and animal products

qas.question: What was included in the local diet?
What forced the need to supplement food supply with nutrition?

plausible_answers.text: region, season, available local plant and animal resources and degree of pastoralism and hunting

qas.question: What did local diets vary by?

context: Another significant change undergone by many of these newly agrarian communities was one of <a0_0><b4_0>diet<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Pre-agrarian diets varied by <b8_0>region, season, available <a1_0><b5_0>local plant and animal resources<b5_0/><a1_0/> and degree of pastoralism and hunting<b8_0/>. Post-agrarian diet was restricted to a limited package of successfully cultivated <a2_0><b6_0>cereal grains, plants and to a variable extent domesticated animals and animal products<b6_0/>.<a2_0/> Supplementation of diet by hunting and gathering was to variable degrees precluded by <a3_0>the <b7_0>increase in population<b7_0/><a3_0/> above the carrying capacity of the land and a high sedentary local population concentration. In some cultures, there would have been a significant shift toward increased starch and plant protein. The relative nutritional benefits and drawbacks of these dietary changes and their overall impact on early societal development is still debated.
